title: Ireland leaves door ajar for 11th-hour Brexit deal
text:
Hopes had dimmed even further after a phone call between Mr Johnson and German Chancellor Angela Merkel on Tuesday that prompted the Prime Minister's aides to anonymously brief that "a deal is essentially impossible not just now but ever".

Some media reports suggested there was genuine movement towards a deal emerging from the meeting. Other commentators said the language of "pathways" was lukewarm at best, and didn't suggest the talks had turned a corner.

The two main sticking points concern the 500km border between the British province of Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland, which is why Mr Varadkar's role is key.

Ireland wants to avoid any kind of trade-impeding border - particularly one that would require putting customs inspection infrastructure on the frontier, creating a potential target of renewed sectarian violence.

But that would mean keeping Northern Ireland in the EU's customs union and single market - and in effect drawing the border between Northern Ireland and the British mainland instead.

Mr Johnson relies on the support of the 10 MPs from Democratic Unionist Party of Northern Ireland, which vehemently opposes any plan that would delineate the province from the rest of Britain.

Advertisement

The impasse has bedevilled the talks for years, and Mr Johnson's deal tried to get around it with two borders: a customs border on the island of Ireland, but without physical checks); and a regulatory (single market) border in the Irish Sea.

Ireland has been unconvinced about the customs plan, and also about Mr Johnson's proposal to allow Northern Ireland leaders a periodic veto on the regulatory plan.

No details were released on Thursday as to what pathway Mr Johnson and Mr Varadkar see for getting out of this, and there was no indication on whether it can be ironed out before a crunch EU leaders' summit next Thursday and Friday.

Are Irish eyes smiling? Ireland's PM Leo Varadkar with British PM Boris Johnson. Getty

Mr Johnson wants to leave on October 31 with no Brexit deal at all if he can't get his latest proposed plan through the EU and his parliament. But MPs have passed a law preventing this.

So if he can't get a deal in the coming days, he'll probably have to ask the EU for a three-month delay to Brexit. He then wants to fight an election as the only party promising to deliver Brexit by January 31 - with or without a deal - and blaming the other parties for failing to leave on October 31.

Opposition Leader Jeremy Corbyn said on Thursday he's ready to fight that election, although some in his Labour Party would rather see Brexit resolved, possibly through a second referendum, before going to the polls.
description: Boris Johnson and Leo Varadkar identify a "pathway" to a deal - but it sounds like there's still a long way to go in a very short time.
